MandibularFractures.Overview: Mandibular fractures are the most common fracture of the face, accounting for about 15.5-59% of all maxillofacial fractures. Among mandibular fractures, the most commonly encountered fracture is condylar fracture.

Factors.StressDistribution: The areas of stress distribution and dissipation depend on the skeletal trabecular architecture.
Factors.InfluencingFactors: Frontal injuries or injuries to the symphysis region are associated with maximum stress being transmitted to the neck of the condyle or the mandibular angle, resulting in fracture of the angle of the mandible bilaterally or of the condylar neck bilaterally. Anatomical factors such as the presence of long roots of teeth and impacted teeth also influence stress concentration.
Factors.IndirectFracture: When stress levels exceed the yield strength/elastic modulus of the bone, an indirect fracture occurs.
